nodes.bodyText: Maybe "Performing conversion" would be more accurate than "Conversion required", as the latter makes it sound like the user needs to do something, but in fact the conversion is automatic (right?)
Yeah - that's a good point.  I'll update it.
Is there a test somewhere that these dates correspond to actual released versions?

The DbSnpIntegrationTest::testDbSnpDataSourceParsing test does part of this already because it uses the latest version of dbSNP to check that it works.
I can add one in to query the google bucket for the min and max versions though.
Did you want to fill in this empty javadoc comment?
Oops!  I sure did!

The ordering of these checks seems problematic to me. Suppose, for example that the minimum supported major+minor version is 1.5, and the maximum supported major+minor version is 3.0. If the actual major+minor version being tested is 2.0, then this method would return false, since 0 < 5, even though 2.0 is between 1.5 and 3.0 and should be compatible with this version of Funcotator.
I think you need to check the minor version only if the major version is equal to either the min or max supported major version. If the major version is between the min and max, the minor version should not matter.
Also you should check that the major version is fully within range (>= MIN and <= MAX) before potentially moving on to examine the minor version.
Agreed.  Sounds good.
I think it's better to avoid fallthrough / combining cases in switch statements, as it's an invitation for future bugs. Recommend separating out the cases as before.

nodes.bodyText: Sure.  Fixed!

nodes.bodyText: I think the import statement collapsing setting in your IDE might be too high -- we definitely want to collapse imports after ~5 or so imports from the same package.
Yup - it was set to 50.  I set it to 5.

You should consider migrating to the newer java.time.* classes (eg., LocalDate) that were introduced in Java 8, instead of using the legacy Calendar class. For example, java.time has a proper Month enum with a Month.of(int) method, which would eliminate the need for a method like this.

Yeah - the old way was deprecated and this was the first solution that I found.  I agree - it's terrible.
I'll switch over to LocalDate or some equivalent.
Did you intend to import this class, or did you mean to import java.util.Collections?
Wow.  No - IntelliJ got a little funny with this one I guess.

Again, what about the case mentioned above of 2.0 (major.minor) being between 1.5 and 3.0?
This DataProvider code is long and complicated and it's difficult for me to confirm that you've covered the important boundary cases. I'd recommend replacing it with a curated and easy-to-read but systematic set of test cases instead -- eg.,
* major < MIN_MAJOR (in which case minor shouldn't matter, so test with various values of minor)
* major = MIN_MAJOR (in which case minor does matter, so again test with various values of minor)
* major > MIN_MAJOR and < MAX_MAJOR (in which case minor shouldn't matter...)
* major = MAX_MAJOR (in which case minor does matter...)
* major > MAX_MAJOR (in which case minor shouldn't matter...)

Then have separate test cases for dates both within and outside the acceptable range, for cases where major and minor are in range.
Sure.  I was trying to automate the tests based on the current acceptable range, then below I had specific test cases for the bounds checking.  I'll refactor as you suggested.
The only issue here is that currently the minimum and maximum major version numbers are the same - 1.  So some of the tests can't really be written (using int values).
Wouldn't need any of this if you switched to java.time as suggested above.
Yup.  Switched to LocalDate.
LocalDate, not Calendar
Oops.  Fixed!

When this method is called in logDataSourcesInfo() and returns false, the UserException message thrown always states that the data source version is too old. However, in reality it might be either too old or too new.
Good point.  I'll fix the log message to be more informative.

I don't think this condition is quite right. If major == MIN_MAJOR, then minor must be >= MIN_MINOR. If major also happens to be == MAX_MAJOR (which it does when MIN_MAJOR == MAX_MAJOR), then minor also needs to be <= MAX_MINOR. So I think we want:
minor >= DataSourceUtils.MIN_MINOR_VERSION_NUMBER && (major != DataSourceUtils.MAX_MAJOR_VERSION_NUMBER || minor <= DataSourceUtils.MAX_MINOR_VERSION_NUMBER)

Yeah - this was tailored to the current values of the MIN_ and MAX_ minor versions.
These tests have been refactored as per some of your other comments, but I'll retain the new conditions.

You can add in a test right now that would cover this case in the future, should the min and max major versions diverge. You can do this by adding a test case conditionally if (MIN_MAJOR_VERSION_NUMBER != MAX_MAJOR_VERSION_NUMBER). That way we don't have to worry about remembering to add this test case in the future.
Ok, cool.  Will do.
Note that the condition might actually need to be that MAX_MAJOR_VERSION_NUMBER - MIN_MAJOR_VERSION_NUMBER > 1, in this case
Yup - I actually already put that condition in 😛

I don't think this condition is right either. We know that major == MAX_MAJOR here, so minor needs to be <= MAX_MINOR. If major also happens to == MIN_MAJOR (which it does when MIN_MAJOR == MAX_MAJOR), then, then minor must also be >= MIN_MINOR. So here I think we want:
minor <= DataSourceUtils.MAX_MINOR_VERSION_NUMBER && (major != DataSourceUtils.MIN_MAJOR_VERSION_NUMBER || minor >= DataSourceUtils.MIN_MINOR_VERSION_NUMBER)

Yeah - this was tailored to the current values of the MIN_ and MAX_ minor versions.
These tests have been refactored as per some of your other comments, but I'll retain the new conditions.

When you check the minor versions, instead of iterating from 0 to 20, you should just check the boundary values 0, MIN_MINOR - 1, MIN_MINOR, MIN_MINOR + 1, MAX_MINOR - 1, MAX_MINOR, MAX_MINOR + 1. After all, you might have a minor version requirement that's > 20 one day.
OK - Fixed!
This should be relative to one of the MIN/MAX constants, otherwise it will break in the future.
Yeah - I didn't want to have to deal with month / year rollover when doing math.  I'll fix it now.
These will also break when the versions are updated -- recommend writing everything in terms of the defined constants.

Actually these won't break when the versions are updated - this is just checking the string formatting of the version numbers, so it should be fine regardless as to what versions we create in the future.
No, it will definitely break as soon as MAX_MAJOR_VERSION_NUMBER is changed to something other than 1, etc., since you've hardcoded the string v1.7.20200521 as the expected value
Ah - right.  I misunderstood.  Fixed.
